{{Infobox academic | honorific_prefix = | name = Séverine Autesserre | image = | occupation = Researcher and professor | known_for = Research on peacebuilding, peacekeeping, and humanitarian aid | title = Professor of Political Science at [[Barnard College]], [[Columbia University]] | awards = <!-- [[Andrew Carnegie Fellowship]] --> | education = [[Yale University]] (post-doctorate), [[New York University]] (Ph.D), [[Columbia University]] (master's degree), [[Sciences Po]] (master's degree), [[Sorbonne University]] (B.A) | alma_mater = <!-- [[Yale University]] --> | discipline = <!-- Political Scientist --> | sub_discipline = <!-- Peacebuilding --> | workplaces = <!-- Associate Professor of Political Science at Barnard College --> | notable_works = ''Peaceland'' (2014)<ref name="auto">{{cite book|last1=Autesserre|first1=Severine|title=Peaceland: Conflict Resolution and the Everyday Politics of International Intervention|date=2014|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|url=http://www.cambridge.org/us/academic/subjects/politics-international-relations/international-relations-and-international-organisations/peaceland-conflict-resolution-and-everyday-politics-international-intervention?format=PB#description}}</ref> and ''The Trouble with the Congo'' (2010)<ref name="auto1">{{cite book|last1=Autesserre|first1=Severine|title=The Trouble with the Congo: Local Violence and the Failure of International Peacebuilding|date=2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|url=http://www.cambridge.org/us/academic/subjects/politics-international-relations/comparative-politics/trouble-congo-local-violence-and-failure-international-peacebuilding?format=PB&isbn=9780521156011}}</ref> | website = www.severineautesserre.com | birth_date={{bda|1976|12|6|df=y}} | birth_place=[[Paris]], France }}
'''Séverine Autesserre''' (born 6 December 1976) is a French author and researcher.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://grawemeyer.org/analysis-of-what-went-wrong-in-congo-wins-grawemeyer-award/|title=Analysis of what went wrong in Congo wins Grawemeyer Award|last=|first=|date=Nov 8, 2011|website=|publisher=Grawemeyer Award|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> She writes about war and peace, [[peacebuilding]], [[peacekeeping]], [[humanitarian aid]], and the ongoing conflict in the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]]. Her research has influenced policy interventions as well as scholarly debates on peacebuilding and on Congo. She is a Professor of Political Science at [[Barnard College]], [[Columbia University]] (New York, USA), where she specializes in international relations and African studies.
== Education ==
Autessere holds a post-doctorate from [[Yale University]] (2007), a Ph.D. in political science from [[New York University]] (2006), master's degrees in international relations and political science from [[Columbia University]] (2000) and [[Sciences Po]] (France, 1999),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://barnard.edu/profiles/severine-autesserre|title=Severine Autesserre - Barnard Faculty Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=Barnard College - Columbia University|publisher=|access-date=15 December 2016}}</ref> respectively, and a B.A in political science from [[University of Paris|Sorbonne University]] (France, 1997).
== Books and scholarly publications ==
Dr. Autesserre's most well-known research focuses on local violence and international intervention in the eastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo. It culminated in her book, ''The Trouble with the Congo: Local Violence and the Failure of International Peacebuilding'', released by Cambridge University Press in 2010.<ref name="auto1"/> This book explains why international efforts to end civil wars so often fail.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Clark|first1=John F.|title=Book review: The Trouble with the Congo|journal=Perspectives on Politics|date=2011|volume=9|issue=4|pages=202–203|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/perspectives-on-politics/article/div-classtitlethe-trouble-with-the-congo-local-violence-and-the-failure-of-international-peacebuilding-by-autesserreseverine-new-york-cambridge-university-press-2010-344p-9000-cloth-2899-paperdiv/83542610EFD83E95092FBA1AE516A2E2|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> Drawing from over 330 interviews and a year and a half of field research, it presents a case study of the international intervention during the Democratic Republic of Congo’s unsuccessful transition from war to peace and democracy (2003–06).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Popiden|first1=Sandra|title=Local dimensions of war and peace in the Democratic Republic of Congo|journal=International Studies Review|date=2013|volume=15|pages=302–306|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/misr.12039/abstract}}</ref> It argues that local rivalries over land, resources, and political power motivated widespread violence. However, an international peacebuilding culture shaped the intervention strategy in a way that precluded action on local conflicts, ultimately dooming the international effort.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nordås|first1=Ragnhild|title=Book Notes: The Trouble With the Congo|journal=Journal of Peace Research|date=November 2012|volume=49|issue=6|pages=873–881}}</ref> [[File:Book_cover_-_The_Trouble_with_the_Congo.jpg|thumb|Book cover - The Trouble with the Congo]]
Research for this project also appeared in [http://afraf.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2012/02/09/afraf.adr080.abstract ''Foreign Affairs'']'', [https://www.cambridge.org/core/product/identifier/S0020818309090080/type/JOURNAL_ARTICLE International Organization], ''the [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/03056240701672510 ''Review of African Political Economy'']'', ''the [https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/african-studies-review/article/div-classtitlelocal-violence-national-peace-postwar-settlement-in-the-eastern-dr-congo-20032006div/8AEB72455D2B584F3725A97610C6B440 ''African Studies Review'']'', ''the [http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/rasr20/20/2 ''African Security Review'']'', [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13533312.2015.1080595 International Peacekeeping], ''the [http://www.relacionesinternacionales.info/ojs/article/view/270/235.html ''Revista de Relaciones Internationales'']'', ''and the ''[http://sites.tufts.edu/jha/pre-2007-articles Journal of Humanitarian Assistance].''
Autessere's second book, ''Peaceland: Conflict Resolution and the Everyday Politics of International Intervention'', was released by Cambridge University Press in 2014<ref name="auto"/> and focuses on the everyday elements that influence peacebuilding interventions on the ground.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://afraf.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2014/11/25/afraf.adu070.extract|title=Peaceland: Conflict resolution and the everyday politics of international intervention|last=Demarest|first=Leila|date=Nov 25, 2014|website=|journal=African Affairs|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> It included extensive fieldwork in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo and briefer comparative research in Burundi, Cyprus, Israel and the Palestinian Territories, South Sudan, and Timor-Leste.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mobydeen|first1=Lana|title=Book Reviews Peaceland: Conflict Resolution and the Everyday Politics of International Intervention|journal=Peace Review|volume=28|issue=3|pages=380–382|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/10402659.2016.1201963|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> The book suggests a new explanation for why international peace interventions so often fail to reach their full potential.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Peake|first1=Gordon|title=If This Is the Way the World Works ...|journal=International Peacekeeping|date=2016|volume=23|issue=1|pages=196–210|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/13533312.2015.1126519}}</ref> It demonstrates that everyday elements – such as the expatriates’ social habits and common approaches to understanding their areas of operation – strongly influence peacebuilding effectiveness.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=H-Diplo|title=Roundtable 9-5 on Peaceland: Conflict Resolution and the Everyday Politics of International Intervention|journal=H-Diplo ISSF Roundtable|date=2016|volume=XI|issue=5|url=https://issforum.org/roundtables/9-5-peaceland|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> Through this analysis of the interveners’ everyday life and work, Peaceland proposes innovative ways to better help host populations build a sustainable peace.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tétreault|first1=M.|title=Peaceland: Conflict resolution and the everyday politics of international intervention|journal=Choice|date=2015|volume=52|issue=5|pages=887–888|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1647791675}}</ref> [[File:Book_cover_for_Peaceland.jpg|thumb|Book cover - Peaceland]]
Findings from this project have also appeared in ''[http://www.sciencespo.fr/ceri/sites/sciencespo.fr.ceri/files/critique_add/art_sa.pdf Critique Internationale]'' and ''[http://afraf.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2012/02/09/afraf.adr080.abstract African Affairs]''.
== Media ==
Autesserre has published columns, essays, and op-eds in many media outlets, including ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2012/11/29/stabilizing-the-democratic-republic-of-congo/start-building-peace-in-congo-at-the-grass-roots-level|title=Start Building Peace in Congo at the Grass-Roots Level|last=|first=|date=29 November 2012|website=New York Times|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> ''[[The Washington Post]]'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2016/10/19/heres-what-this-island-in-congo-can-teach-the-world-about-peace/|title=Here’s what Congo can teach the world about peace|last=|first=|date=19 October 2016|website=Monkey Cage – The Washington Post|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> ''[[Foreign Affairs]]'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/democratic-republic-congo/2008-05-03/trouble-congo|title=The Trouble With Congo|last=|first=|date=2008|website=Foreign Affairs|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> ''[[Foreign Policy]]'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/10/06/trouble-in-peaceland-united-nations-congo-development/|title=Trouble in Peaceland|last=|first=|date=6 October 2015|website=Foreign Policy|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> ''[http://africanarguments.org/2012/08/01/the-continuing-trouble-with-the-congo-by-severine-autesserre/ African Arguments]'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://africanarguments.org/2012/08/01/the-continuing-trouble-with-the-congo-by-severine-autesserre/|title=The Continuing Trouble with the Congo|last=|first=|date=1 August 2012|website=African Arguments|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> ''The International Herald Tribune'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/23/opinion/the-only-way-to-help-congo.html?pagewanted=all|title=The Only Way to Help Congo - The Opinion Pages - Global New York Times|last=Autesserre|first=Severine|date=June 22, 2012|work=|access-date=December 12, 2016|via=}}</ref> among others. She has also been a frequent guest on various other broadcast media, include television and radio, and in 2014 she gave a [[TED Talks|TED talk]] that has since been translated into 19 languages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ted.com/talks/severine_autesserre_to_solve_mass_violence_look_to_locals|title=Séverine Autesserre, TED talk|last=|first=|date=|website=TED website|publisher=|access-date=Jan 9, 2017}}</ref>
== Teaching == Professor Autesserre has taught at [[New York University]], [[Yale University]] and currently teaches at [[Columbia University]]'s [[Barnard College]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://barnard.edu/profiles/severine-autesserre|title=Severine Autesserre - Barnard Faculty Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=Barnard College - Columbia University|publisher=|access-date=12 December 2016}}</ref> [[School of International and Public Affairs, Columbia University|School of International and Public Affairs]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sipa.columbia.edu/faculty/s-verine-autesserre|title=Séverine Autesserre, SIPA faculty profile|last=|first=|date=|website=SIPA website|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> and Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. She teaches graduate and undergraduate classes in [[Political Science]], [[Human Rights]], and African Studies, and she advises doctoral students.
== Influence and awards == According to [[Google Scholar]], Dr. Autesserre's work has been cited in [https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=uJt8odkAAAAJ&hl=en more than 1,900] scholarly texts, including more than [https://scholar.google.com/scholar?oi=bibs&hl=en&cites=18284947723613336595,10639451684674028899,12277483694318593174,15678577545649401637,11449412497252309522,17137646550195337269,15518952348744297567,15787453503439890058 650] works citing ''The Trouble With the Congo'' and more than [https://scholar.google.com/scholar?oi=bibs&hl=en&cites=1773918121262217732,11603782889310602456,814438852845099225,15526147527626781848,1704733872155876633 350] works citing ''Peaceland''.
Her research and publications have also influenced public debates and policies on international peacebuilding and on the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]]. Her two books positioned Autesserre as "an authoritative voice" on international humanitarian interventions.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Review of "The Trouble with the Congo" and "Peaceland",|url=http://www.budrich-journals.de/index.php/eris/article/view/19360/16859|journal=European Journal of International Relations|volume=2|issue=1|pages=121–127|last1=Veit|first1=Alex}}</ref> Her publications on peacebuilding have helped shape intervention strategies for several United Nations departments,<ref name="Benner 169–178">{{Cite journal|last=Benner|first=Thorsten|date=2011-11-01|title=Heart of Darkness|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00396338.2011.621642|journal=Survival|volume=53|issue=5|pages=169–178|doi=10.1080/00396338.2011.621642|issn=0039-6338}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Going around in circles: peacekeeping and stabilization in Congo|last=de Vries|first=Hugo|publisher=Clingendael institute|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=http://www.clingendael.nl/sites/default/files/going_around_in_circles.pdf}}</ref> foreign affairs ministries, philanthropists,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.insidephilanthropy.com/home/2016/8/18/when-it-comes-to-promoting-peace-where-can-funding-do-the-mo.html|title=When It Comes to Promoting Peace, Where Can Funding Do the Most Good?|newspaper=Inside Philanthropy|access-date=2017-01-08}}</ref> activists,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/12/business/media/kony-2012-video-illustrates-the-power-of-simplicity.html|title=‘Kony 2012’ Video Illustrates the Power of Simplicity|last=Cohen|first=Noam|date=2012-03-11|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2017-01-08}}</ref> and non-governmental organizations. She has testified before the U.S. Congress<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://foreignaffairs.house.gov/hearing/subcommittee-hearing-resolving-political-crisis-democratic-republic-congo/|title=Subcommittee Hearing: Resolving the Political Crisis in the Democratic Republic of the Congo - Committee on Foreign Affairs|work=Committee on Foreign Affairs|access-date=2017-12-03|language=en-US}}</ref>, and her research was quoted in debates at the U.S. House of Representatives<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://financialservices.house.gov/uploadedfiles/052113_mpt_memo2.pdf|title=Memorandum - Subject: May 21, 2013, Monetary Policy and Trade Subcommittee Hearing on “The Unintended Consequences of Dodd-Frank’s Conflict Minerals Provision”.|last=United States House of Representatives Committee on Financial Services|first=|date=May 16, 2013|work=|access-date=January 8, 2016|via=}}</ref> and the Canadian Congress.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?Language=f&Mode=1&Parl=40&Ses=3&DocId=4808372|title=Comités de la Chambre des communes - SDIR (40-3) - Témoignages - Numéro 033|website=www.parl.gc.ca|access-date=2017-01-08}}</ref> Her publications have helped put local conflict resolution on the agenda of policy-makers and practitioners working in Congo.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201309200262.html|title=Congo-Kinshasa: Q&A - Congolese Wrongly Branded As "Pathological"|last=Legatis|first=Rousbeh|date=2013-09-20|newspaper=Inter Press Service|access-date=2017-01-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lemarchand|first=René|date=2013-11-01|title=REFLECTIONS ON THE RECENT HISTORIOGRAPHY OF EASTERN CONGO*|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-african-history/article/reflections-on-the-recent-historiography-of-eastern-congo/9433B1B511EC75FD0BB44FEC8E97E06C|journal=The Journal of African History|volume=54|issue=3|pages=417–437|doi=10.1017/S002185371300073X|issn=0021-8537}}</ref>
She is regularly invited to present her research in the [[United States]], but also internationally, including in [http://asiapacific.anu.edu.au/cap-events/2016-10-26/international-dynamics-making-peace-and-preventing-atrocity-where-do-we-stand Australia], [http://aaapucrio.com.br/palestra-peaceland-conflict-resolition-and-the-everyday-politics-of-international-intervention/ Brazil], [http://ustpaul.ca/en/peaceland-conflict-resolution-and-the-everyday-politics-of-international-intervention_2238_17.htm Canada], [http://www.sciencespo.fr/newsletter/archive-89cf3607e585ebd092b8e55d9897f190.html France], [https://www.bicc.de/press/press-releases/press/news/lecture-peaceland-by-severine-autesserre-478/ Germany], the [https://www.rsc.ox.ac.uk/events/2016-annual-elizabeth-colson-lecture-peaceland-conflict-resolution-and-the-everyday-politics-of-international-intervention United Kingdom,] [http://www.nai.uu.se/events/Severine-Autesserre-5-May-2015.pdf Sweden], and [http://koff.swisspeace.ch/fileadmin/user_upload/koff/Documents/Invitation_KOFF_Roundtable_Success_and_Failure.pdf Switzerland], to name a few countries.
Autesserre's research on Congo has won multiple prizes and awards. Her first paper won the 2006 Best Graduate Student Paper award from the African Studies Association,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.africanstudies.org/awards-prizes/graduate-student-paper-prize/96-awards-prizes/306-graduate-student-paper-prize-winners|title=Graduate Student Paper Prize Winners|website=African Studies Association|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> and her article "Dangerous Tales" won the 2012 Best Article award from the African Politics Conference Group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://africanpoliticsgroup.org/index.php/publications/awards/#bestarticle|title=African Politics Conference Group - Past Awards|website=African Politics Conference group|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> The same year, her book ''The Trouble with the Congo'' won the prestigious [[Grawemeyer Award]] for Ideas Improving World Order<ref>{{cite web|url=http://grawemeyer.org/analysis-of-what-went-wrong-in-congo-wins-grawemeyer-award/|title=Analysis of what Went Wrong in Congo Wins Grawemeyer Award|website=Grawemeyer Awards|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> (at the time, she was the youngest recipient of the [[Grawemeyer Award]]). The book also won the 2011 [[Chadwick Alger Prize]] presented by the International Studies Association to the best book on international organizations and multilateralism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isanet.org/Programs/Awards/Chadwick-Alger/Past-Recipients|title=Chadwick Alger Prize - Past Recipients|website=International Studies Association|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref>
Autesserre's work on the everyday dimensions of [[peacebuilding]] also won several book prizes. ''Peaceland'' won the 2016 Best Book of the Year Award<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isanet.org/Programs/Awards/ISA-Annual-Best-Book|title=ISA Annual Best Book Award|website=International Studies Association|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> and the 2015 Yale H. Ferguson Award<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isanet.org/Programs/Awards/Yale-H-Ferguson/Past-Recipients|title=Yale H. Ferguson Award - Past Recipients|website=International Studies Association}}</ref> from the [[International Studies Association]], as well as honorable mentions for three other book prizes: the 2014 African Argument Book of the Year,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://africanarguments.org/2015/01/05/african-arguments-book-of-the-year/|title=African Arguments Book of the Year|website=African Arguments|last1=African Arguments Editor|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> the 2015 Chadwick Alger Prize from the International Studies Association,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isanet.org/Programs/Awards/Chadwick-Alger/Past-Recipients|title=Chadwick Alger Prize - Past Recipients|website=International Studies Association}}</ref> and the 2015 Conflict Research Society Book of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://conflictresearchsociety.org/the-conflict-research-society-book-of-the-year/|title=The Conflict Research Society Book of the Year|website=CRS - Conflict Research Society|accessdate=25 December 2016}}</ref>
Her research has won her numerous other prizes and fellowships, including a [http://www.fondcrf.org/evenements/les-prix-de-recherche/#toggle-id-1 Special Prize of the Jury from the French Red Cross Fund] (2017), an [[Carnegie Corporation of New York|Andrew Carnegie Fellowship]] (2016),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.carnegie.org/news/articles/andrew-carnegie-fellows-program-recognizes-33-scholars-significant-work-social-sciences-and-humanities/|title=Announcing the 2016 Andrew Carnegie Fellows|last=|first=|date=19 April 2016|website=Carnegie Corporation of New York|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.politicalsciencenow.com/meet-carnegie-fellow-severine-autesserre//|title=Meet Carnegie Fellow Severine Autesserre|last=|first=|date=5 August 2016|website=Political Science Now|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> a 2016 [[Foreign Policy Interrupted]] fellowship, two research awards from the [[United States Institute of Peace]] (2004–05 and 2010–12),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.usip.org/newsroom/multimedia/video-gallery/the-trouble-the-congo-0|title=The Trouble with the Congo|last=|first=|date=|website=United States Institute of Peace|publisher=|access-date=14 December 2016}}</ref> two [[Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation]] research grants (2010 and 2011), a Presidential Research Award from Barnard College (2010), several grants from Columbia University (2010–13), two Mellon Fellowships in Security and Humanitarian Action (2004–06), and a Fulbright Fellowship (1999–2000).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.womeninforeignpolicy.org/academia/2016/12/4/severine-autesserre-associate-professor-barnard-college-columbia-university|title=Interview with Séverine Autesserre|last=|first=|date=5 December 2016|website=Foreign Policy Interrupted|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
She is one of the seven main characters in Timothy Pachirat´s book [https://www.routledge.com/Among-Wolves-Ethnography-and-the-Immersive-Study-of-Power/Pachirat/p/book/9780415528986 ''Among Wolves''].<ref>Timothy Pachirat, ''[https://www.routledge.com/Among-Wolves-Ethnography-and-the-Immersive-Study-of-Power/Pachirat/p/book/9780415528986 Among Wolves: Ethnography and the Immersive Study of Power]''. Routledge, 2017.</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Tony Robbins | image = Tony Robbins.jpg | caption = Robbins in 2009 | birth_name = Anthony J. Mahavoric | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|2|29|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[North Hollywood, California]], U.S. | partner = Liz Acosta | occupation = {{hlist|Entrepreneur, author, motivational speaker}} | years_active = 1978–present | known_for = Motivational speaker | spouse = {{marriage|Becky Robbins|1984|1997}}
{{marriage|Sage Robbins |2001}} | children = 4, including [[Jairek Robbins]] }} '''Anthony Jai Robbins''' (born '''Anthony J. Mahavoric'''; February 29, 1960) is an American [[author]], [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]], [[Philanthropy|philanthropist]] and [[Coaching|life coach]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/tony-robbins-life-story-2015-6|title=How celebrity coach Tony Robbins spends his millions|work=Business Insider|access-date=June 29, 2017|language=en}} Robbins is known for his [[infomercial]]s, [[seminar]]s, and [[self-help book]]s including ''[[Unlimited Power]]'' and ''Awaken the Giant Within''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/marianne-schnall/interview-with-tony-robbi_b_6190678.html|title=Interview with Tony Robbins on His New Book, 'Money: Master the Game'|last=Schnall|first=Marianne|date=November 20, 2014|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=June 29, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2017/02/24/927584/0/en/Feeding-America-to-Ring-The-Nasdaq-Stock-Market-Opening-Bell.html|title=Feeding America to Ring The Nasdaq Stock Market Opening Bell|last=Inc.|first=NASDAQ,|work=GlobeNewswire News Room|access-date=June 29, 2017|language=en-US}} Robbins is the founder of several companies that earn approximately $6 billion in annual sales. In 2015 and 2016 he was listed on the ''[[Worth (magazine)|Worth Magazine]]'' Power 100 list.{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxla.com/good-day/good-day-la-celebrity-interviews/114882911-story|title=Tony Robbins: "Money: Master the Game"|last=FOX|work=KTTV|access-date=June 29, 2017|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.worth.com/power-100-2016/|title=The Power 100 {{!}} 2016|date=October 17, 2016|work=Worth|access-date=October 18, 2017|language=en-US}} ==Early life== Robbins was born as Anthony J. Mahavoric in [[North Hollywood, California]], on February 29, 1960.{{Cite news |first=Brian |last=O'Keefe |date=October 31, 2014 |title=Tony Robbins, The CEO Whisperer |magazine=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |url=http://fortune.com/2014/10/30/tony-robbins-best-advice-executive-coach/ |accessdate=November 1, 2014 }} Robbins is the eldest of three children and his parents divorced when he was 7. His mother then remarried (more than once), including a marriage with Jim Robbins, a former semi-professional baseball player who legally adopted Anthony when he was 12.{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2014/10/30/tony-robbins-best-advice-executive-coach/|title=Tony Robbins, The CEO Whisperer|last=O'Keefe|first=Brian|website=Fortune|access-date=June 29, 2017|date=October 30, 2014}} Tony Robbins was raised in [[Glendora, California|Glendora]], California, and attended [[Glendora High School]]. He was elected student body president in his senior year. While growing up, Robbins worked as a handyman to help provide for his siblings.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1991-10-01/news/vw-3520_1_tony-robbins/3|title=A True Believer: Tony Robbins Has Attracted Converts – and Critics – to His Positive-Thinking Empire|last=Granberry|first=Michael|date=October 1, 1991|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|access-date=June 29, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}} During high school, Robbins grew ten inches, a growth spurt later attributed to a [[pituitary tumor]]. He has said his home life was "chaotic" and "abusive". When he was seventeen years old, he left home and never returned. Robbins later worked as a janitor, and did not attend college. ==Career== Robbins began his career promoting seminars for [[motivational speaker]] and author [[Jim Rohn]] when he was 17 years old.{{cite web|url=http://motivationlife.com/?p=27 |title=Anthony Robbins: A true motivation life |accessdate=December 31, 2009 |publisher=MotivationLife |author=Rolando Ponce de Leon |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016135441/http://motivationlife.com/?p=27 |archivedate=October 16, 2009 }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.success-guide.com/tony-robbins-tribute-jim-rohn/|title=Tony Robbins tribute to Jim Rohn - Success Guide|website=www.success-guide.com|language=en-US|access-date=July 2, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.success.com/mobile/article/who-inspires-tony-robbins|title=Who Inspires Tony Robbins?|date=November 17, 2016|work=SUCCESS|access-date=July 2, 2017|language=en|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170710100055/http://www.success.com/mobile/article/who-inspires-tony-robbins|archivedate=July 10, 2017}} In the early 1980s, soon after meeting [[Neurolinguistic Programming]] co-founder [[John Grinder]], the two became partners. At this time Robbins taught NLP and [[Ericksonian hypnosis|Ericksonian Hypnosis.]] In 1983 Robbins learned to firewalk, and incorporated it into his seminars.{{Cite book|title=Awaken the Giant Within: How to Take Immediate Control of Your Mental, Emotional, Physical and Financial Destiny|last=Robbins|first=Tony|publisher=Free Press|year=2007|isbn=0-671-79154-0|location=|pages=}} In 1988 Robbins released his first infomercial, Personal Power, produced by [[Guthy Renker]],{{Cite book|title="Guthy-Renker Corporation," International Directory of Company Histories.|last=Brynildssen|first=Shawna|last2=Smith|first2=Dawn M.|publisher=St. James Press|year=2011|isbn=|edition=Karen Hill|volume=119|location=Detroik|pages=}} which helped to promote his services as a "peak performance coach". The infomercial helped Robbins gain wide exposure, selling his Personal Power self-help [[audiotapes]]. His early infomercials featured celebrities such as [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] [[quarterback]] [[Fran Tarkenton]] and actor [[Martin Sheen]]. (2017) (co-authored with Peter Mallouk) {{ISBN|1501164589}} == Teachings == === Personal performance === Throughout his writings, seminars, and speeches, Robbins espouses viewpoints, techniques, and other practices he asserts can help adherents improve their lives.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/08/fashion/08With.html|title=With Tony Robbins, Self-Help Author|last=Ellin|first=Abby|date=August 6, 2010|work=The New York Times|access-date=July 18, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} He speaks about various "human needs, influences that affect people, the power of making decisions" and the need to achieve "emotional mastery".{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/marianne-schnall/life-purpose_b_1461184.html|title=An In-depth Interview With Life Coach Tony Robbins|last=Schnall|first=Marianne|date=April 29, 2012|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=July 18, 2017}}{{Citation|last=Tony Robbins|title=Science of Achievement & Art of Fulfillment {{!}} Tony Robbins|date=January 21, 2016|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e27DT3LemSQ|accessdate=July 18, 2017}} === Seminars === Robbins holds multiple seminars annually. These seminars include ''Unleash the Power Within'', ''Date with Destiny'', ''Life and Wealth Mastery'', ''Business Mastery'' and ''Leadership Academy''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/tony-robbins-self-help-guru-is-larger-than-life/2014/12/01/4253e516-75ae-11e4-bd1b-03009bd3e984_story.html|title=Tony Robbins, Self-Help Guru, is Larger Than Life|last=Heller|first=Karen|date=December 1, 2014|website=Washington Post|access-date=July 18, 2017}} === Health and energy === "Energy: The Fuel of Excellence", a chapter in ''Unlimited Power'', is dedicated to a discussion of health and energy. It endorses the ''Fit For Life'' program of [[Fit for Life|Harvey and Marilyn Diamond]], food combining and deep breathing. Robbins refers to Harvey and Marilyn Diamond as his "former partners".{{Cite book|title=Unlimited Power|last=Robbins|first=Tony|publisher=Fawcett Columbine (Ballantine Books)|year=1987|isbn=0-449-90280-3|location=|pages=}} ==Philanthropy== === The Tony Robbins Foundation === In 1991, Robbins founded the [[Anthony Robbins Foundation]],{{Cite web|url=https://anthonyrobbinsfoundation.org/about/our-history/|title=Our History - Anthony Robbins Foundation|website=anthonyrobbinsfoundation.org|access-date=July 16, 2017}} intended to help youth, homeless, hungry, prisoners, elderly and disabled.{{cite web | url = http://www.anthonyrobbinsfoundation.org/about/our-mission/| title = Our Mission | publisher = Anthony Robbins Foundation | accessdate = July 15, 2015 }}{{Cite web|url=https://anthonyrobbinsfoundation.org/programs/basket-brigades/|title=Basket Brigade - Anthony Robbins Foundation|website=anthonyrobbinsfoundation.org|access-date=July 16, 2017}} The organization's name was subsequently changed to "The Tony Robbins Foundation." In 2016 Robbins and his Foundation partnered with [[Bob Carr]] and the [[Give Something Back Foundation]] on the ''ROC 'N Robbins Challenge'' event. Carr matched the $1 million Robbins donated at the event, with the proceeds going to send 100 low-income students to medical school.{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/marianne-schnall/tony-robbins-and-bob-carr_b_10180152.html|title=Tony Robbins and Bob Carr Join Forces to Change the World One Child at a Foundation a rating of four out of four stars in 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm/bay/search.summary/orgid/9985.htm|title=Anthony Robbins Foundation|year=2016|publisher=Charity Navigator Ratings|accessdate=September 8, 2014|author=Charity Navigator}} === Feeding America === In 2014, he donated the profits of his book, ''Money: Master
